original_title: Impossible WiFi on an Ancient Mac Portable
original_content:
The Macintosh Portable was possibly one of the coolest computing devices to be seen with back at the end of the 1980s, providing as it did a Mac in a slightly nicer version of the hefty luggable portables of the day than the PC world could offer. Inside was a mere 68000, but it ran Mac OS system 6 and looked light years ahead of any comparable PC in doing so.
Back in 1989 it wasnt even the norm for a computer to have built-in Ethernet, and WiFi was still a gleam in the eye of some Dutch engineers, so how has [Joshua Stein] managed to get his Mac Portable on a wireless network here in 2023? The answer contains a few surprises.
When seeing a WiFi upgrade for a classic retrocomputer the usual expectation is that its done by emulating a modem connection to the Internet over a serial port. But this wireless network card is a bit different, its a real network card capable of being used for much more than just connecting to the Internet.
We have to admit to not knowing that there were SCSI Ethernet interfaces back in the day, and its one of these that hes created. Hes building on a decades work in producing disk emulators for the SCSI bus, and hes taken the code for a Raspberry Pi Pico version and adapted the SCSI driver part to interface with the onboard WiFi on a Pico W. Altogether its a beautiful piece of work, and you can color us impressed.
title: 1980年代末のMacintosh PortableにWiFiを追加してみた
body: 1980年代末に登場したMacintosh Portableは、PCの重い携帯型コンピュータよりも優れたマッキントッシュを提供しました。内部には68000が搭載されていましたが、Mac OSシステム6を実行し、他のPCに比べて先進的でした。現代の2023年において、Joshua SteinさんはMac Portableをワイヤレスネットワークに接続することができました。これは一般的にはモデム接続をエミュレートすることで行われることが期待されますが、彼は実際のネットワークカードを使用しています。SCSIイーサネットインターフェースを使い、Raspberry Pi Picoのコードを適応させました。全体として、素晴らしい仕事です。
